g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Ninety percent of tropical peatland carbon stocks are vulnerable to
emission during conversion and may not be recoverable through restoration; in
temperate peatlands hold similar carbon stocks (1,439
carbon stocks are vulnerable to emission during conversion and irrecoverable through restoration
. A recent study shows global mitigation potential of about 0.2 GtCO
). Another study estimated that 72% of mitigation is achieved
through avoided soil carbon impacts, with the remainder through avoided impacts to vegetation
. Recent model projections show that both peatland protection and peatland restoration
(Section 7.4.2.7) are needed to achieve a 2ºC mitigation pathway and that peatland protection and
restoration policies will have minimal impacts on regional food securit
Global studies have not accounted for extensive peatlands recently reported
in the Congo Basin, estimated to cover 145,500 km2 and contain 30.6 Pg C, as much as 29% of total
. These Congo peatlands are relatively intact; continued
underlain by permafrost (roughly 50% of the total peatlands north of 23º latitud
major driver of peatland degradation (e.g. through permafrost thaw)
reduction of peatland conversion is also a cost
ffective mitigation strategy. Peatlands are sensitive to
about the future peatland sink globally (SRCCL, Chapter
2). Permafrost thaw may shift northern peatlands from a net carbon sink to net source
. Uncertainties in peatland extent and the magnitude of existing carbon stocks, in both northern
latitudes limit understanding of current and future

benefits particularly in tropical countries, support the effectiveness of t
. Feasibility of reducing peatland conversion may depend on countries’

ulation in vegetation and soils and avoids ongoing CO
for about 3% of the terrestrial surface, predominantly occurring in boreal ecosystems (78%), with a

benefits for biodiversity, as well as regulating water flow and
, while still allowing for extensive management such as paludiculture
etting of peatlands also reduces the risk of fire, but may also mobilize salts and
and in severely degraded peatlands, restoration of
peatland hydrology and vegetation may not be feasible
restoration of peatlands drained for agriculture could displace food production and damage local
supply, although impacts to regional and global food security would be minimal
. Collaborative and transparent planning processes are needed to reduce conflict between
policies are key to engage local communities and maintain livelihood
